docs.lead_paragraph: A year ago, I got a bicycle that changed my life. The sort of bicycling that attracts me is nothing like those leisurely rides through the countryside, a soft breeze in your face, stopping to picnic or explore a stream along the way.

headline.main: Fast Pace, Hard Seat: Now That's Cycling

docs.abstract: Increase in sales of specialty road bicycles from 171,600 in 2002 to 185,400 in 2003 reflects growing interest in serious cycling in United States; five-time Tour de France winner Lance Armstrong's influence is cited as partial cause for growth in cycling; new bicycle technologies, including custom cycles with computerized features and ultra lightweight frames, can reduce rider injuries and make extended riding more fluid; suggestions for proper bicycle fit and adjustments described; photos (L)
docs.snippet: A year ago, I got a bicycle that changed my life.     The sort of bicycling that attracts me is nothing like those leisurely rides through the countryside, a soft breeze in your face, stopping to picnic or explore a stream along the way.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve raised its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday for the first time in four years, officially signaling that a remarkable period of historically low rates is drawing to a close. But even as it increased the cost of borrowing for financial institutions on overnight loans to 1.25 percent from 1 percent, it sought to soothe investors by saying that inflationary pressures remained low and that further rate increases should come at a ''measured'' pace.

headline.main: FEDERAL RESERVE RAISES KEY RATE A QUARTER POINT

docs.abstract: Federal Reserve raises its benchmark interest rate for first time in four years, officially signaling that remarkable period of historically low rates is drawing to close; cost of borrowing for financial institutions on overnight loans is raised to 1.25 percent from 1 percent; Fed issues statement that could be good news for Pres Bush; it indicates that even though it expects to keep increasing interest rates as Nov elections approach, economic impact of increases is likely to be mild until at least sometime next year; because Fed chairman Alan Greenspan and other top officials had telegraphed their intentions months in advance, stock market takes move in stride and yields on long-term Treasury securities actually decline slightly; Bush and Sen John Kerry react cautiously; photo; graph; chart (M)
